Event.name: Fragmentation_scenario
Event.definition:
<def-root>A <fen>Whole</fen> fragments or breaks into <fen>Parts</fen>, or alternatively a part, <fen>Part_1</fen>, breaks off from the rest of the item, called <fen>Part_2</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Time">Last year</fex>, <fex name="Part_1">it</fex> <t>broke</t> <fex name="Part_2">off from the Ross Ice Shelf</fex> and began drifting out to sea. </ex>
<ex><fex name="Whole">The calved ice</fex> <t>broke</t> <fex name="Parts">into three large icebergs, named A22, A23 and A24</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Whole
Arg.definition: <def-root>The <fen>Whole</fen> is a single entity which breaks into <fen>Parts</fen>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Parts
Arg.definition: <def-root>This refers collectively to the Parts resulting from fragmentation of a Whole.</def-root>

Arg.name: Part_1
Arg.definition: <def-root>Part-1 is the first of two Parts mentioned. This is most often the external argument of a verb.</def-root>

Arg.name: Part_2
Arg.definition: <def-root>Part_2 is the second of two Parts mentioned. This is usually a PP Complement.</def-root>

Arg.name: Criterion
Arg.definition: <def-root>This frame element expresses a property of the Parts or components of the <fen>Whole</fen> which correlates with the locations (e.g.) of fragmentation on the <fen>Whole</fen>.</def-root>

Arg.name: Depictive
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies any <fen>Depictive</fen> phrase describing any of the undergoers of the fragmentation.</def-root>

Arg.name: Result
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Result</fen> of an event.</def-root>

Arg.name: Time
Arg.definition: <def-root>This FE identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the fragmenting occurs.</def-root>

Arg.name: Resistant_surface
Arg.definition:
<def-root>The hard surface against which the <fen>Whole</fen> (or <fen>Part_1</fen>) breaks.
<ex>Too fragile a knife will <t>shatter</t> <fex name="res">on the stone</fex>.</ex></def-root>

Arg.name: Means
Arg.definition:
<def-root>An action or state that enables the fragmentation.
<ex>As the energy of the string increases, it <t>fragments</t> <fex name="mea">by producing quark-antiquark (or diquark-antidiquark) pairs at the breakpoints</fex>.</ex></def-root>
